The dates for the frosh and soph
banquet season has been set for
April 24, 25 and 26 at a meeting in
Latrobe held by the officers of the
freshman and sophomore classes and
presided over by William McLean,
president of the Student Council.
Difficulty is being experienced by
the presidents of the classes as to
the type of "entertainment" to provide for the members of their
classes. The good old-fashioned days
of "rough and tumble" were advocate by McLean, who also desired to
crowd the season into the space of
two days. Tom Ellis and Vernon
Grove, presidents of the freshman
and sophomore classes, respectively,
were, however, in favor of a threeday affair with a little gentler
amusement for their classmates.
William B. Kempton, chairman of
the Freshman Banquet Committee,
announced that chairmen and their
committees have been appointed for
the various tasks connected with arrangements. He also said that everything is coming along with great
progress and greater ease than he
expected.

Acraunameisamo

Pictures By Dean Berry
Create Great Surprise
Dean Berry displayed a hitherto
unknown side of his many interests
when he contributed several paintings
done by himself for an exhibition of
paintings by doctors of Baltimore.
His paintings deal with several subjects Dean Berry saw while in South
America. They were carefully sketched
and planned while there and completed at home.
The chief aim of these pictures, according to their artist, is to catch the
color of the various subjects. Strange
as it may be, drawing and painting
are not recent acquisitions with Dean
Berry, as he has been doing that sort
of thing all his life. The Deann has
utilized his talents to draw the fossils
for his books and for decorative purposes. The drawing of a hornless
rhinoceros in his office is a splendid
example of the latter.
Water-color pictures haven't received much attention from him during the past few years—a fact which
the Dean blames on the time spent
on NEWS-LETTER reporters.
The
friends of Dean Berry have expressed
pleasant surprise at his artistic talents, and his exhibited pictures have
attracted much attention.

Debating
Debaters W rangle
On Arms Shipment
By STANLEY E. BLUMBERG
Approximately twenty undergraduates, augmented by two fair members of the College for Teachers,
were privileged to sit in yesterday
on one of the most unique debates
ever to be held at the University.
Meeting under the Oregon system,
representatives of the University of
Cincinnati and the Johns Hopkins
departed from the monotonous formality so associated with debating
and raked each other over the coals
in a decidedly intimate and spirited
manner.
The Oregon system provides for a
presentation speech, a cross-examination, and a rebuttal on the part of
each team. It was during the crossexamination period that yesterday's
debate asserted its unique nature
and drew uniform approval from the
apparently amazed audience.
Lyons Acts As Chairman
After introductory remarks by
Dr. Clifford Lyons, who served as
chairman, Sylvan Garfunkel, of Hopkins, stated the affirmative side of
the question: Resolved, That the nations of the world shall agree to prohibit the international shipment of
arms and munitions. He stressed
the nefarious activities of the munitions makers, as evidenced by the
Nye Senate investigation, and also
maintained that an embargo on arms
would forward the cause of world
peace.
In presenting the case of the negative, Samuel Edlavitch flatly declared that the proposed embargo
would prove impossible of execution.
Assuming for the sake of argument,
however, that such a plan was feasible, he pointed out that it would be

great play, which has been produced
every evening this week since Tuesday, will be presented tonight and tomorrow night at 8:30 in the Playshop by the Johns Hopkins Playshop.
Included in the cast of the play,

Kirby Page, author and editor, will
be the featured speaker at a TriState intercollegiate seminar on
"Christianity and Modern Social Issues" to be held at Levering Hall,
Wednesday, at 4 P. M.
Mr. Page was born in Texas in
1890. He received his A. B. degree
from Drake University in 1915, and
was ordained to the ministry of the
Disciples of Christ.
He has been attached to Y. M. C.
A. periods since 1908, ,when he became assistant secretary of the
Houston, Texas, organization. He did
"Y" work in England and France
during 1916 and 1917.
From 1926 to 1934, Mr. Page was
editor of The World Tomorrow. He
has written many books, among
them, "Something More," "Jesus or
Christianity," and "Individualism and
Socialism."
He lives with his wife and two children in Long Island City, New York.
Admission to the conference, which
will last until 10 P. M., will be 50
cents for students and 75 cents for
members of the faculty,
The order of events is given as
follows:
Order Of Events
4:00 p. m.—Opening session
Opening Prayer or Brief Service
of Worship.
Short Statement about Seminar
by presiding officer.
Address: "After the New Deal
What?", Kirby Page.
Period for questions and discussion.
6:00 p. m.—Intermission.
6:30 p. m.—Dinner: Informal Fellowship.
7:45 p. m. — Address: "Religion's
Contribution to Social Justice",
Kirby Page.
Period for discussion with a view
to next steps and what we can
do.
9:30 p. m.—Closing Worship, conducted by the speaker.
10:00 p. m.—Adjournment.

Dr. Beard Lectures
wice Next Week
Dr. Charles A. Beard, renowned
historian and political commentator,
will come to the Johns Hopkins University next week to lecture under
the James Schouler Foundation.
Dr. Beard, whose ideas and opinions have caused considerable comment among academic and political
circles during the last few years, will
present two public lectures at 5 P.
M., Monday and Tuesday, in Latrobe
Hall. He will spend the remainder
of the week on the campus.
"History As Art and Science" will
be the subject of the first address.
On Tuesday, Dr. Beard will speak on
"History Speaks for Itself."

A student up at Dartmouth wished
to get home a few days before vacation, and employed the following
clever method. The boy sent a telegram home asking whether he should
come home by way of Toronto, or
come straight home. "Come straight
home," the family wired. With this
in his possession, the student readily
obtained the necessary permission to
go home.

A professor at the University of
Washington found, not unreasonably,
that all his finer sensibilities and illusions were being outraged by the
constant powdering, rouging, and repowdering indulged in by his co-ed
students during the course of a lecture.
Finally he rebelled and entered
into a deep conspiracy with one of his
male students.
The next morning this individual
entered the lecture room, sat down
in the front row, pulled out pocket
mirror, brush, soap, mug, and razor,
and proceeded leisurely to shave himself before his agonized audience.

Just got word from Joe, the campus barber, that for the price of a
single hair-cut, you are privileged
to listen to the latest music via radio, and the latest campus scandal
via his stooge, Bob, the copper. Joe
is figuring on adding a pretty manicurist to his staff, and Bob is already devising ways to handle the
huge crowds expected, when and if
that day ever comes. When all these
facts are put together, what a pretty
picture it makes. Reclining in the
barber's chair, swift hands shaving
you, jazz music in your left ear; campus gossip in your right ear, and a
pretty manicurist tickling you under
the nails, and a greater joy than all
put together, is the Chem lecture
that you are _missing.

The form assumed by the new
style of make-up marks a very definite and distinct journalistic retrogression. You will find on looking
through the Evening Sun of 100
years ago exactly the same style.
You will find, on examining any
well-established newspaper during
the past 75 years of its history, that
the head-line scheme has slowly
evolved from the simple, unassuming, unimpressive, dead style which
you have adopted to the system used
today by every American paper—
the system which you have seen fit
to supplant by out-moded monotony
You are quite mistaken when you
so solemnly announce that "headlines are the raison d'etre" of journalists. Has it ever occurred to you
that the headlines tend to make
newspaper less difficult? In your
new type of page every article is to
the reader of equal importance. He
must run through an entire page of
practically unbroken print to find a
few obscured articles carefully ancl
maliciously hidden in the maze. Under the old system, a brief of every
article smashed us in the face. We
missed nothing; we had no difficulty whatever in finding or reading
what we wished.
Do you realize that a great number of the men on the NEWS-LETTER
staff are there only to build up a
little experience as a foundation for
writing after college? The argument that the New Journalism will
simplify matters for the staff will
defeat its own ends. It is true that
the staff will have less actual work
to do, but they will get far less for
their trouble. Work with the New
Journalism will give a man only negative experience for real journalism.
It seems to me unfortunate that
the NEWS-LETTER should adopt a
system which hinders the first purpose of any newspaper—to present
news in a clear style, easy to read—

Editor of the NEWS-LETTFR:
Dear Sir:
It has been just about a year ago
that the Spirit moved me to write for
your columns; but it is not the Spirit
moving me this time; it is the editorial
you have filled up much of the space
on this page—"Panacea For Man."
How in the name of common sense
any sane thinking person can arrive
at such illogical conclusions as you
propound is more than my feeble
brain can imagine.
Don't you know that without propagation it would be only a matter of
time until "the sands of time shall be
no more"? I suppose you would enjoy such a situation, that is, being
among the last men on earth.
To make yourself feel more smug
in your opinions you cite Mencken
(of all people), Shaw, Socrates, Plato,
etc., as being brainy and childless,
therefore proving that all brainy men,
"philosophers", are the only people
on the face of this good old earth
who have any common sense. But
what are you going to say about
Roosevelt, Woodrow Wilson, Mussolini, Theodore Roosevelt, and yes, Eddie Cantor?
Would you have us believe that the
great Theodore Roosevelt had no other outlet for his ego than the manufacture of squawling infants? Oh,
no, my good man, far from it. There
was a man who realized that propagation of the race was the only true
way to continue existence. And existence, after all, is nothing to be taken
lightly, even if you and some other
iconoclasts happen to have no regard
for it.
The so-called problems of the human race will never be solved by
such a selfish, ultra-modern method.
No children, indeed! I can refer you
to no less an authority, than the
Good Book, wherein several chapters
are taken up with describing how the
grand old patriarchs of ancient times
"begat" sons and daughters; those
sons and daughters went off into foreign territory and "begat" other sons
and daughters. In other words, it Is
an old Spanish custom and one which
will never be broken up by any phobias of mere "philosophers" now or
forever, amen!
For myself, I will always be for
the good old days when a father was
a father and a family was five, six,
seven, eight (or how many have you)
R. A. Z.
children.

Richmond, Va.—The elimination of
"weak colleges" has been recommended to the western section of the World
lliance of Presbyterian and Reformed
churches by its committee on Christian education.
In a report presented to delegates
representing the 13,000,000 Presbyterians of North America who assembled here for a two-day congress,
Dr. James E. Clarke reported that
although many colleges of the constituent churches had been handicapped during the last two years by
financial conditions, "it is gratifying
to be able to report now that most of
these colleges seem to have made a
virtue of necessity.
"While it is possible that they are
today less efficient, it is certain their
financial status has greatly improved," the report said.

Ann Arbor, Mich.—Those who have
to do with the constructions of law
school curriculums these days are
having their troubles---that is, if we
are to listen to Henry M. Bates, dean
of the University of Michigan's
famed law school.
"More and more the legal profession is called on, not to get its clients
out of trouble, but to prevent them
from getting into trouble," he said.
"We are confident that a better arrangement than the orthodox treatments of those subjects in the public
law is possible."
Recommending the revision of law
school curriculums to meet changes in
business and industry, the dean said:
"These changes (in business and industry) undeniably have produced
shifts and changes of emphasis in the
kinds litigation and of legal services
of all kinds. Thus, the law in relation
to many matters in the field of commerce and property has become settled . . . so that litigation in those
fields has relatively declined."

The dates for the frosh and soph
banquet season has been set for
April 24, 25 and 26 at a meeting in
Latrobe held by the officers of the
freshman and sophomore classes and
presided over by William McLean,
president of the Student Council.
Difficulty is being experienced by
the presidents of the classes as to
the type of "entertainment" to provide for the members of their
classes. The good old-fashioned days
of "rough and tumble" were advocate by McLean, who also desired to
crowd the season into the space of
two days. Tom Ellis and Vernon
Grove, presidents of the freshman
and sophomore classes, respectively,
were, however, in favor of a threeday affair with a little gentler
amusement for their classmates.
William B. Kempton, chairman of
the Freshman Banquet Committee,
announced that chairmen and their
committees have been appointed for
the various tasks connected with arrangements. He also said that everything is coming along with great
progress and greater ease than he
expected.

Pictures By Dean Berry
Create Great Surprise
Dean Berry displayed a hitherto
unknown side of his many interests
when he contributed several paintings
done by himself for an exhibition of
paintings by doctors of Baltimore.
His paintings deal with several subjects Dean Berry saw while in South
America. They were carefully sketched
and planned while there and completed at home.
The chief aim of these pictures, according to their artist, is to catch the
color of the various subjects. Strange
as it may be, drawing and painting
are not recent acquisitions with Dean
Berry, as he has been doing that sort
of thing all his life. The Deann has
utilized his talents to draw the fossils
for his books and for decorative purposes. The drawing of a hornless
rhinoceros in his office is a splendid
example of the latter.
Water-color pictures haven't received much attention from him during the past few years—a fact which
the Dean blames on the time spent
on NEWS-LETTER reporters.
The
friends of Dean Berry have expressed
pleasant surprise at his artistic talents, and his exhibited pictures have
attracted much attention.

Debating
Debaters W rangle
On Arms Shipment
By STANLEY E. BLUMBERG
Approximately twenty undergraduates, augmented by two fair members of the College for Teachers,
were privileged to sit in yesterday
on one of the most unique debates
ever to be held at the University.
Meeting under the Oregon system,
representatives of the University of
Cincinnati and the Johns Hopkins
departed from the monotonous formality so associated with debating
and raked each other over the coals
in a decidedly intimate and spirited
manner.
The Oregon system provides for a
presentation speech, a cross-examination, and a rebuttal on the part of
each team. It was during the crossexamination period that yesterday's
debate asserted its unique nature
and drew uniform approval from the
apparently amazed audience.
Lyons Acts As Chairman
After introductory remarks by
Dr. Clifford Lyons, who served as
chairman, Sylvan Garfunkel, of Hopkins, stated the affirmative side of
the question: Resolved, That the nations of the world shall agree to prohibit the international shipment of
arms and munitions. He stressed
the nefarious activities of the munitions makers, as evidenced by the
Nye Senate investigation, and also
maintained that an embargo on arms
would forward the cause of world
peace.
In presenting the case of the negative, Samuel Edlavitch flatly declared that the proposed embargo
would prove impossible of execution.
Assuming for the sake of argument,
however, that such a plan was feasible, he pointed out that it would be

Kirby Page, author and editor, will
be the featured speaker at a TriState intercollegiate seminar on
"Christianity and Modern Social Issues" to be held at Levering Hall,
Wednesday, at 4 P. M.
Mr. Page was born in Texas in
1890. He received his A. B. degree
from Drake University in 1915, and
was ordained to the ministry of the
Disciples of Christ.
He has been attached to Y. M. C.
A. periods since 1908, ,when he became assistant secretary of the
Houston, Texas, organization. He did
"Y" work in England and France
during 1916 and 1917.
From 1926 to 1934, Mr. Page was
editor of The World Tomorrow. He
has written many books, among
them, "Something More," "Jesus or
Christianity," and "Individualism and
Socialism."
He lives with his wife and two children in Long Island City, New York.
Admission to the conference, which
will last until 10 P. M., will be 50
cents for students and 75 cents for
members of the faculty,

follows:

Opening Prayer or Brief Service

by presiding officer.

What?", Kirby Page.
Period for questions and discussion.

Contribution to Social Justice",
Kirby Page.
Period for discussion with a view
to next steps and what we can
do.
9:30 p. m.—Closing Worship, conducted by the speaker.
10:00 p. m.—Adjournment.

A student up at Dartmouth wished
to get home a few days before vacation, and employed the following
clever method. The boy sent a telegram home asking whether he should
come home by way of Toronto, or
come straight home. "Come straight
home," the family wired. With this
in his possession, the student readily
obtained the necessary permission to
go home.

A professor at the University of
Washington found, not unreasonably,
that all his finer sensibilities and illusions were being outraged by the
constant powdering, rouging, and repowdering indulged in by his co-ed
students during the course of a lecture.
Finally he rebelled and entered
into a deep conspiracy with one of his
male students.
The next morning this individual
entered the lecture room, sat down
in the front row, pulled out pocket
mirror, brush, soap, mug, and razor,
and proceeded leisurely to shave himself before his agonized audience.

Just got word from Joe, the campus barber, that for the price of a
single hair-cut, you are privileged
to listen to the latest music via radio, and the latest campus scandal
via his stooge, Bob, the copper. Joe
is figuring on adding a pretty manicurist to his staff, and Bob is already devising ways to handle the
huge crowds expected, when and if
that day ever comes. When all these
facts are put together, what a pretty
picture it makes. Reclining in the
barber's chair, swift hands shaving
you, jazz music in your left ear; campus gossip in your right ear, and a
pretty manicurist tickling you under
the nails, and a greater joy than all
put together, is the Chem lecture
that you are _missing.

The form assumed by the new
style of make-up marks a very definite and distinct journalistic retrogression. You will find on looking
through the Evening Sun of 100
years ago exactly the same style.
You will find, on examining any
well-established newspaper during
the past 75 years of its history, that
the head-line scheme has slowly
evolved from the simple, unassuming, unimpressive, dead style which
you have adopted to the system used
today by every American paper—
the system which you have seen fit
to supplant by out-moded monotony
You are quite mistaken when you
so solemnly announce that "headlines are the raison d'etre" of journalists. Has it ever occurred to you
that the headlines tend to make
newspaper less difficult? In your
new type of page every article is to
the reader of equal importance. He
must run through an entire page of
practically unbroken print to find a
few obscured articles carefully ancl
maliciously hidden in the maze. Under the old system, a brief of every
article smashed us in the face. We
missed nothing; we had no difficulty whatever in finding or reading
what we wished.
Do you realize that a great number of the men on the NEWS-LETTER
staff are there only to build up a
little experience as a foundation for
writing after college? The argument that the New Journalism will
simplify matters for the staff will
defeat its own ends. It is true that
the staff will have less actual work
to do, but they will get far less for
their trouble. Work with the New
Journalism will give a man only negative experience for real journalism.
It seems to me unfortunate that
the NEWS-LETTER should adopt a
system which hinders the first purpose of any newspaper—to present
news in a clear style, easy to read—

Editor of the NEWS-LETTFR:
Dear Sir:
It has been just about a year ago
that the Spirit moved me to write for
your columns; but it is not the Spirit
moving me this time; it is the editorial
you have filled up much of the space
on this page—"Panacea For Man."
How in the name of common sense
any sane thinking person can arrive
at such illogical conclusions as you
propound is more than my feeble
brain can imagine.
Don't you know that without propagation it would be only a matter of
time until "the sands of time shall be
no more"? I suppose you would enjoy such a situation, that is, being
among the last men on earth.
To make yourself feel more smug
in your opinions you cite Mencken
(of all people), Shaw, Socrates, Plato,
etc., as being brainy and childless,
therefore proving that all brainy men,
"philosophers", are the only people
on the face of this good old earth
who have any common sense. But
what are you going to say about
Roosevelt, Woodrow Wilson, Mussolini, Theodore Roosevelt, and yes, Eddie Cantor?
Would you have us believe that the
great Theodore Roosevelt had no other outlet for his ego than the manufacture of squawling infants? Oh,
no, my good man, far from it. There
was a man who realized that propagation of the race was the only true
way to continue existence. And existence, after all, is nothing to be taken
lightly, even if you and some other
iconoclasts happen to have no regard
for it.
The so-called problems of the human race will never be solved by
such a selfish, ultra-modern method.
No children, indeed! I can refer you
to no less an authority, than the
Good Book, wherein several chapters
are taken up with describing how the
grand old patriarchs of ancient times
"begat" sons and daughters; those
sons and daughters went off into foreign territory and "begat" other sons
and daughters. In other words, it Is
an old Spanish custom and one which
will never be broken up by any phobias of mere "philosophers" now or
forever, amen!
For myself, I will always be for
the good old days when a father was
a father and a family was five, six,
seven, eight (or how many have you)
R. A. Z.
children.

Richmond, Va.—The elimination of
"weak colleges" has been recommended to the western section of the World
lliance of Presbyterian and Reformed
churches by its committee on Christian education.
In a report presented to delegates
representing the 13,000,000 Presbyterians of North America who assembled here for a two-day congress,
Dr. James E. Clarke reported that
although many colleges of the constituent churches had been handicapped during the last two years by
financial conditions, "it is gratifying
to be able to report now that most of
these colleges seem to have made a
virtue of necessity.
"While it is possible that they are
today less efficient, it is certain their
financial status has greatly improved," the report said.

Ann Arbor, Mich.—Those who have
to do with the constructions of law
school curriculums these days are
having their troubles---that is, if we
are to listen to Henry M. Bates, dean
of the University of Michigan's
famed law school.
"More and more the legal profession is called on, not to get its clients
out of trouble, but to prevent them
from getting into trouble," he said.
"We are confident that a better arrangement than the orthodox treatments of those subjects in the public
law is possible."
Recommending the revision of law
school curriculums to meet changes in
business and industry, the dean said:
"These changes (in business and industry) undeniably have produced
shifts and changes of emphasis in the
kinds litigation and of legal services
of all kinds. Thus, the law in relation
to many matters in the field of commerce and property has become settled . . . so that litigation in those
fields has relatively declined."
